oversight_info.authority: South Korea: Ministry of Food and Drug Safety

brief_summary.textblock: The hypothesis of this study is that in staged bilateral total knee arthroplasty (TKA, magnesium sulfate administered during the perioperative period of the first TKA may decrease pain after the second TKA. It is known that pain is greater in the second TKA than in the first. Therefore, we compared pain of the second TKA between the magnesium and control groups.

clinical_study.study_design: Allocation: Randomized, Endpoint Classification: Efficacy Study, Intervention Model: Parallel Assignment, Masking: Double Blind (Subject, Caregiver, Investigator, Outcomes Assessor), Primary Purpose: Prevention

primary_outcome.time_frame: from the end of the TKA until 48 hour
primary_outcome.description: Pain measured with visual analogue scale (VAS)

secondary_outcome.time_frame: from the end of the TKA until 48 hours
secondary_outcome.description: analgesic consumptions from the end of the TKA until 48 hours

arm_group.description: Control group receive same volume of normal saline as in the magnesium group
This group receive magnesium sulfate perioperatively.

intervention.description: The magnesium group receive intravenous magnesium sulfate.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria: American society of anesthesiologist physical status 1 - 2. patients scheduled to undergo staged bilateral TKA
Exclusion Criteria: American society of anesthesiologist physical status >3
